books.description: Nineteen Eighty-Four is a dystopian social science fiction novel and cautionary tale written by the English writer George Orwell. It was published on 8 June 1949 by Secker & Warburg as Orwell's ninth and final book completed in his lifetime.
books.author: George Orwell

books.title: Notes from Underground
books.description: Notes from Underground is a novel by Fyodor Dostoevsky, first published in the journal Epoch in 1864. It is a first-person narrative in the form of a ''confession'': the work was originally announced by Dostoevsky in Epoch under the title ''A Confession''.
books.author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky

books.title: The Brothers Karamazov
books.description: The Brothers Karamazov, also translated as The Karamazov Brothers, is the last novel by Russian author Fyodor Dostoevsky. Dostoevsky spent nearly two years writing The Brothers Karamazov, which was published as a serial in The Russian Messenger from January 1879 to November 1880.
books.author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky

books.title: Brave New World
books.description: Brave New World is a dystopian novel by English author Aldous Huxley, written in 1931 and published in 1932.
books.author: Aldous Huxley

books.title: The Tempest
books.description: The Tempest is a play by English playwright William Shakespeare, probably written in 1610–1611, and thought to be one of the last plays that Shakespeare wrote alone.
books.author: William Shakespeare

books.title: The Stranger
books.description: The Stranger, also published in English as The Outsider, is a 1942 novella by French author Albert Camus. Its theme and outlook are often cited as examples of Camus' philosophy, absurdism, coupled with existentialism; though Camus personally rejected the latter label.
books.author: Albert Camus

books.title: Corpus Hermeticum
books.author: Hermes Trismegistus
books.description: The Corpus Hermeticum is a collection of 17 Koine Greek pseudepigraphical writings whose authorship is traditionally attributed to the legendary Hellenistic figure Hermes Trismegistus, a syncretic combination of the Greek god Hermes and the Egyptian god Thoth.

books.title: The Sacred Mushroom And The Cross
books.description: The Sacred Mushroom and the Cross: A Study of the Nature and Origins of Christianity Within the Fertility Cults of the Ancient Near East is a 1970 book about the linguistics of early Christianity and fertility cults in the Ancient Near East. It was written by John Marco Allegro.
books.author: John M. Allegro

books.title: Atlas Shurgged
books.description: Atlas Shrugged is a 1957 novel by Ayn Rand. Her fourth and final novel published during her lifetime, it was also her longest, and the one she considered to be her magnum opus in the realm of fiction writing.
books.author: Ayn Rand

books.title: Fahrenheit 451
books.description: Fahrenheit 451 is a 1953 dystopian novel by American writer Ray Bradbury. Often regarded as one of his best works, Fahrenheit 451 presents an American society where books have been outlawed and ''firemen'' burn any that are found.
books.author: Ray Bradbury

books.title: The Giver
books.description: The Giver is a 1993 American young adult dystopian novel written by Lois Lowry, set in a society which at first appears to be utopian but is revealed to be dystopian as the story progresses.
books.author: Lois Lowry

books.title: Don Quixote
books.description: Don Quixote is a Spanish epic novel by Miguel de Cervantes. Originally published in two parts, in 1605 and 1615, its full title is The Ingenious Gentleman Don Quixote of La Mancha or, in Spanish, El ingenioso hidalgo don Quixote de la Mancha.
books.author: Gustave Doré

cart.title: Notes from Underground

cart.author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky

cart.title: Brave New World
cart.description: Brave New World is a dystopian novel by English author Aldous Huxley, written in 1931 and published in 1932.
cart.author: Aldous Huxley

cart.description: The Tempest is a play by English playwright William Shakespeare, probably written in 1610–1611, and thought to be one of the last plays that Shakespeare wrote alone.
cart.author: William Shakespeare

cart.author: Fyodor Dostoyevsky

cart.author: George Orwell
